case_id: State of Tamil Nadu v. Ravi (Alias Ravichandran) (2006) 5 SCC 188
facts: The case involves an appeal by Ravi alias Ravichandran (A1) against his conviction for murder.
A1 (Ravi), A2 (Munuswamy), and A3 (Babu) were charged with the murder of Raji (wife of A1).
Incident occurred during the night intervening 30.09.1995 and 01.10.1995 at the residence of A1 and the deceased in MGR Nagar, Chennai.
Prosecution alleged motive: A1 had an illicit relationship with Vasantha (wife of A2). The deceased (Raji) objected to this relationship, leading to frequent quarrels.
Allegation: A1, A2, and A3 conspired and murdered Raji. A1 allegedly strangulated her with a rope (M.O.1), while A2 and A3 held her legs.
PW1 (brother of the deceased) filed the complaint.
Post-mortem examination (conducted by PW4) revealed the cause of death as asphyxia due to strangulation, noting a ligature mark on the neck.

Key prosecution witnesses included PW1 (complainant, deposed about motive/quarrels), PW2 (neighbour, initially hostile, later partially supported prosecution regarding quarrels), PW3 (neighbour, deposed about motive/quarrels).
A1 allegedly made a confessional statement leading to the recovery of the rope (M.O.1) under Section 27 of the Indian Evidence Act.
Trial Court: Convicted A1 under Section 302 IPC and sentenced him to life imprisonment. Acquitted A2 and A3.
High Court: Confirmed the conviction and sentence of A1. The State did not appeal against the acquittal of A2 and A3.
Supreme Court: A1 appealed against the High Court's judgment confirming his conviction.
ipc_sections: Section 34 (Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention) - Primarily relevant at trial stage for A2/A3, implicitly considered regarding A1's sole act.

prosecution_arguments.argument: A1's guilt for murder under Section 302 IPC is proven beyond reasonable doubt through a complete chain of circumstantial evidence.
precedents: Sharad Birdhichand Sarda v. State of Maharashtra (1984) 4 SCC 116
Hanumant Govind Nargundkar v. State of M.P. AIR 1952 SC 343
State of U.P. v. Ashok Kumar Srivastava (1992) 2 SCC 86
elements: Death was caused by the act of A1.
Act was done with the intention of causing death (mens rea).

counter_arguments.loophole: Chain of circumstantial evidence has weak links; possibility of alternative hypothesis not fully excluded.
supporting_precedents: Padala Veera Reddy v. State of A.P. AIR 1990 SC 79
Wakkar v. State of U.P. (2011) 3 SCC 306
Kali Ram v. State of Himachal Pradesh (1973) 2 SCC 808

prosecution_arguments.argument: Strong motive (illicit relationship and deceased's objections leading to quarrels) is established through witness testimony (PW1, PW2, PW3), strengthening the circumstantial case.
precedents: Suresh Chandra Bahri v. State of Bihar AIR 1994 SC 2420
Nathuni Yadav v. State of Bihar (1998) 9 SCC 238
G. Parshwanath v. State of Karnataka (2010) 8 SCC 593
elements: Resultant conflict/quarrels proximate to the incident.

counter_arguments.loophole: Motive evidence primarily from related (PW1) or neighbour witnesses (PW2, PW3) who could be biased or unreliable; PW2 turned hostile initially.
supporting_precedents: M. Narsinga Rao v. State of A.P. (2001) 1 SCC 691
State of Punjab v. Bittu (2015) 10 SCC 578
Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab AIR 1953 SC 364

prosecution_arguments.argument: Recovery of the weapon (rope - M.O.1) at the instance of A1 under Section 27 of the Evidence Act corroborates his involvement.
precedents: Pulukuri Kottaya v. Emperor AIR 1947 PC 67
Mohd. Inayatullah v. State of Maharashtra (1976) 1 SCC 828
State of Karnataka v. David Rozario (2002) 7 SCC 728
elements: Information received from accused in police custody.
Information led to the discovery of a fact.
The fact discovered was deposed to.
The fact discovered is distinctly related to the information given.

counter_arguments.loophole: Admissibility under Section 27 is questionable due to potential lack of voluntariness, non-compliance with procedural safeguards (e.g., independent witnesses), or the discovered item being non-incriminating/planted.
supporting_precedents: Selvi v. State of Karnataka (2010) 7 SCC 263
Mustkeem alias Sirajudeen v. State of Rajasthan (2011) 11 SCC 724
State of Rajasthan v. Bhup Singh (1997) 10 SCC 675

prosecution_arguments.argument: Medical evidence (post-mortem report by PW4) clearly establishes homicidal death by strangulation, consistent with the prosecution's case of murder by A1 using a rope.
precedents: Balbir Singh v. State of Punjab (2006) 12 SCC 149
Kehar Singh v. State (Delhi Admn.) (1988) 3 SCC 609
Mulla v. State of U.P. (2010) 3 SCC 508
elements: Consistency between injuries and alleged weapon/manner of assault.
Confirmation of homicidal nature of death.

counter_arguments.loophole: Medical evidence confirms strangulation but does not directly identify the perpetrator.
supporting_precedents: Mangat Ram v. State of Haryana (2014) 12 SCC 595
Malkhan Singh v. State of M.P. (2003) 5 SCC 746
State of U.P. v. Ram Swarup (1974) 4 SCC 764

defense_arguments.argument: The prosecution case relies solely on circumstantial evidence, and the chain is not complete; crucial links are missing or weak, failing the standard set by Sharad Birdhichand Sarda.
edge_cases: PW2's initial hostility casts doubt on neighbourhood testimony.
Time gap between last alleged quarrel and the incident.
Lack of direct evidence placing A1 at the scene *at the exact time* of strangulation.
precedents: Sharad Birdhichand Sarda v. State of Maharashtra (1984) 4 SCC 116
Sujit Biswas v. State of Assam (2013) 12 SCC 406
Ashish Jain v. Makrand Singh (2019) 3 SCC 770

defense_arguments.argument: The alleged recovery of the rope (M.O.1) under Section 27 Evidence Act is unreliable and does not conclusively link A1 to the crime.
edge_cases: Absence of independent witnesses during recovery.
Possibility of the rope being a common household item planted by police.
Questionable voluntariness of the statement leading to discovery.
precedents: Asar Mohammad v. State of U.P. (2019) 12 SCC 253
Pankaj Kumar Singh v. State of Jharkhand (2021) 11 SCC 600
Bobcombe Cannu v. State of Karnataka (2022) SCC Online SC 1489

defense_arguments.argument: The testimonies of PW1 (brother) and PW3 (neighbour) regarding motive are biased and interested; PW2's testimony is unreliable due to initial hostility. Lack of independent corroboration.
edge_cases: Normal familial/neighbourly disputes being exaggerated post-incident.
Inconsistencies in witness accounts of quarrels.
precedents: Hari Obula Reddy v. State of A.P. (1981) 3 SCC 675
Sachin Kumar Singhraha v. State of Madhya Pradesh (2019) 6 SCC 55
Raju v. State of Haryana (2010) 3 SCC 235

defense_arguments.argument: Acquittal of A2 and A3 weakens the overall prosecution story, especially the conspiracy angle and the alleged manner of holding the deceased.
edge_cases: If A2/A3 were not involved, the prosecution's initial version of events is demonstrably flawed.
Implausibility of A1 overpowering and strangulating the deceased single-handedly without struggle marks noted.
precedents: Brathi v. State of Punjab (1991) 1 SCC 519 (Discrepancy between charge and finding)
State of Rajasthan v. Kishore (1996) 3 SCC 217 (Impact of acquittal of co-accused)
Insufficient data - Specific precedents on how co-accused acquittal impacts remaining conviction based on circumstantial evidence would require deeper search.

judgment.outcome: Appeal Dismissed. Conviction of A1 (Ravi alias Ravichandran) under Section 302 IPC upheld.
reasoning: The Supreme Court concurred with the findings of the Trial Court and High Court.
The chain of circumstantial evidence was found to be complete and pointing conclusively towards the guilt of A1.
Motive (illicit relationship, deceased's objection, quarrels) was held to be convincingly established through the testimony of PW1, PW2 (despite initial hostility, later corroborated parts), and PW3.
Medical evidence (strangulation) corroborated the prosecution's case regarding the manner of death.
The recovery of the rope (M.O.1) at the instance of A1 under Section 27 of the Evidence Act was considered valid and reliable corroborative evidence.
Testimonies of PW1 and PW3 were found credible despite their relationship/position as neighbours, as their evidence was consistent and appeared natural.
The Court found no perversity in the appreciation of evidence by the lower courts warranting interference in the concurrent findings of guilt against A1.
The acquittal of A2 and A3 did not necessarily destroy the case against A1, as the evidence specifically pointed to A1's role in the strangulation based on motive, recovery, and other circumstances.
